Literature Review: Active colloids represent a fascinating class of materials that can convert energy inputs into directed motion and dynamic assemblies. These systems are characterized by their ability to operate far from thermodynamic equilibrium, breaking time-reversal symmetry and enabling a wide range of emergent behaviors. In this review, we explore three primary types of active colloids: those driven by chemical reactions, time-varying magnetic fields, and electric currents. Each type offers unique insights into the fundamental principles governing active matter and opens new avenues for the development of advanced materials and machines.
